                                       to Assessment
52.04 Entering Land to Destroy Weed or 52.09 Duty of City Personnel
Growths: Notice
52.05 Failure to Comply
Â 
52.01Â Â Â DEFINITIONS.Â Â 
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The following weeds or growths are hereby declared to be noxious and
shall be divided into two classes, namely:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Primary noxious weeds or growths, which shall include quack grass
(Agropyron repens), perennial sow thistle (Sonchus arvensis), Canada thistle
(Cirsium arvense), bull bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), horse nettle (Solanum
carolinense), leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula), perennial peppergrass (Lepidium
draba), Russian knapweed (Centaurea repens), buckthorn (Rhamnus, not to include
Rhamnus frangula, and all other species of thistles belonging in genera of
Cirsium and Carduus).
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Secondary noxious weeds or growths, which shall include butterprint
(Abutilon theophrasti) annual, cocklebur (Xanthium commune) annual, wild
mustard (Brassica arvensis) annual, wild carrot (Daucus carota) biennial,
buckhorn (Plantago lanceolata) perennial, sheep sorrel (Rumex acetosella)
perennial, sour dock (Rumex crispus) perennial, smooth dock (Rumex altissimus)
perennial, poison hemlock (Conium maculatum), multiflora rose (Rosa
multiflora), wild sunflower (wild strain of Helianthus annuus L.) annual,
puncture vine (Tribulus terrestris) annual, teasel (Dispsacus) biennial, and
shattercane (Sorghum bicolor) annual. The multiflora rose (Rosa multiflora)
shall not be considered a secondary noxious weed or growth when cultivated for
or used as understock for cultivated roses or as ornamental shrubs in gardens,
or in the City when the City Council has by resolution declared it not to be a
noxious weed or growth. Shattercane (Sorghum bicolor) shall not be considered a
secondary noxious weed or growth when cultivated or in the City when the City
Council has by resolution declared it not to be a noxious weed or growth.
Â Â Â Â Â Â "Noxious weeds or growths" also include any grasses growing over 8 inches
tall or other growths declared to be noxious by the City Council by resolution.
(Ord. 05-2016 - Aug. 16 Supp.)
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â â€œWeed Commissionerâ€ refers to an individual duly appointed by motion or
resolution of the City Council or the Commissionerâ€™s deputy or designee to
carry out the functions set out in this chapter.
52.02Â Â Â COMMISSIONER: DIRECTION AND CONTROL.
Â Â Â The Commissioner, subject to direction and control by the City Council,
shall supervise the control and destruction of all noxious weeds or growths
whenever found in the City including those growing within the limits of
cemeteries, along streets and highways as well as railroad right-of-way or
property. The Commissioner may enter upon any land in the City at any time for
the performance of the Commissionerâ€™s duty, and shall hire the labor and
equipment necessary, subject to the approval of the City Council.
52.03Â Â Â DECLARATION AS A NUISANCE.
Â Â Â Any noxious weeds or growths found growing in any lot or tract of land in
the City are hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and it is unlawful to
permit any such weeds or growths to grow or remain in any such place. Each
owner and each person in the possession or control of any lands shall cut,
burn, or otherwise destroy, in whatever manner may be prescribed by the City
Council or Commissioner, all noxious weeds or growths thereon as defined in
this chapter at such times in each year and in such manner as shall be
prescribed by order of the City Council or Commissioner, and shall keep said
lands free from such growth of any weeds or growths that shall render the
streets or highways adjoining said land unsafe for public travel.
52.04Â Â Â ENTERING LAND TO DESTROY WEEDS OR GROWTHS: NOTICE.
Â Â Â In case of a substantial failure by the owner or person in possession or
control of any land to comply with any order of destruction pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter, the Weed Commissioner, the Weed Commissionerâ€™s
deputies, and employees acting under the Weed Commissionerâ€™s direction shall
have full power and authority to enter upon any land within the City for the
purpose of destroying noxious weeds or growths. Such entry may be made without
the consent of the landowner or person in possession or control of the land but
actual work of destruction shall not be commenced until five days after the
service of a notice in writing on the landowner and/or on the person in
possession or in control of the land. The notice shall state the facts as to
failure of compliance with the City program of weed or growth destruction order
or orders made by the City Council and shall be served in the same manner as an
original notice except as hereinafter provided. The notice may be served by the
Weed Commissioner, the Weed Commissionerâ€™s deputies, or any person designated
in writing by the Weed Commissioner and filed in the office of the City Clerk;
provided, however, service on persons living temporarily or permanently outside
of the City may be made by sending the written notice of noncompliance by
certified mail to said person at the last known address to be ascertained, if
necessary, from the last tax list in the County Treasurerâ€™s office. Where any
person owning land within the City has filed a written instrument in the office
of the County Auditor designating the name and address of its agent, the notice
herein provided may be served on that agent. In computing time hereunder, the
time begins from the date of mailing as evidenced by the certified mail
receipt.
52.05Â Â Â FAILURE TO COMPLY.
Â Â Â In case of a substantial failure to comply by the date prescribed in any
order of destruction of weeds or growths made pursuant to this chapter, the
Weed Commissioner or the deputies may, subsequent to the time after service of
the notice provided for in Section
52.04, enter upon the land and cause the weeds or growths to be destroyed or
may impose a maximum penalty of a $10.00 fine for each day, up to ten days,
that the owner or person in control of the land fails to comply. If a penalty
is imposed and the owner or person in control of the land fails to comply, the
Weed Commissioner shall cause the weeds or growths to be destroyed, the actual
cost and expense of cutting, burning or otherwise destroying the weeds or
growths, along with the cost of serving notice and special meetings or
proceedings, if any, shall be paid by the City and together with the additional
assessment to apply toward costs of supervision and administration, be
recovered by an assessment against the tract of real estate on which the weeds
or growths were growing. Any fine imposed shall be recovered by a similar
assessment.
52.06Â Â Â EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS: USE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
Â Â Â The City Council may appropriate moneys for the purpose of purchasing weed
or growth eradicating equipment and materials to carry out the duties of the
Commissioner for use on all lands in the City, public or private, and for the
payment of the necessary expenses and compensation of the Commissioner, and the
Commissionerâ€™s deputies, if any. When equipment or materials so purchased are
used on private property within the corporate limits of the City by the
Commissioner, the cost of materials used and an amount to be fixed by the City
Council for the use of the equipment shall be returned by the County Treasurer
upon the collection of the special assessment taxed against the property. In
the certification to the County Treasurer by the City Clerk, this apportionment
shall be designated along with the special tax assessed.
52.07Â Â Â LOSS OR DAMAGE TO CROPS OR PROPERTY.
Â Â Â The loss or damage to crops or property incurred by reason of such
destruction shall be borne by the title holder of said real estate, unless said
real estate shall be sold under contract whereby possession has been delivered
to the purchaser, in which event such purchaser shall bear such loss or damage,
excepting where a contract has been entered into providing a different
adjustment for such loss or damage.
52.08Â Â Â ASSESSMENT OF COSTS: HEARING PRIOR TO ASSESSMENT.
Â Â Â When the Commissioner destroys any weeds or growths under the authority of
this chapter, after failure of the landowner responsible to destroy such weeds
or growths pursuant to the order of the City Council or Commissioner, the cost
of destruction shall be assessed against the land and collected from the
landowner responsible in the following manner:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Semiannually, or as necessary, after the Weed Commissioner has
completed the destruction of weeds or growths by reason of noncompliance by
persons responsible therefor, the Commissioner shall determine as to each tract
of real estate the actual cost of labor and materials used by the Commissioner
in cutting, burning, or otherwise destroying said weeds or growths, the cost of
serving notice and special meetings or proceedings, if any. To the total of all
such sums expended, the Commissioner shall add an amount equal to 25 percent
thereof to compensate for the cost of supervision and administration and assess
the resulting sum against said tract of real estate by a special tax, which
shall be certified to the County Auditor and County Treasurer by the City
Clerk, and shall be placed upon the tax books and collected, together with
interest and penalty after due, in the same manner as other unpaid taxes. Such
tax shall be due on March 1 after such assessment, and shall be delinquent
after March 30. When collected, said funds shall be paid into the fund from
which said costs were originally paid.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Before making any such assessment, the City Council shall prepare a
plat or schedule showing the several lots, tracts of land, or parcels of ground
to be assessed, which shall be in accord with the assessorâ€™s records and the
amount proposed to be assessed against each of the same for destroying or
controlling weeds or growths during the fiscal year.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The City Council shall thereupon fix a time for the hearing on such
proposed assessments, which time shall not be later than December 15 of the
year, and at least 20 days prior to the time thus fixed for such hearing shall
give notice thereof to all concerned that such plat or schedule is on file, and
the amounts as shown therein will be assessed against the several lots, tracts
of land or parcels of ground described in said plat or schedule at the time
fixed for such hearing, unless objection is made thereto. Notice of such
hearing shall be given by one publication in the official newspaper of the City
or by posting a copy of such notice on the premises affected and by mailing a
copy by certified mail to the last known address of the person owning or
controlling said premises. At such time and place the owner of said premises or
anyone liable to pay such assessment may appear, with the same rights given by
law before boards of review in reference to assessments for general taxation.
52.09Â Â Â DUTY OF CITY PERSONNEL.
Â Â Â It is the duty of all City personnel to make complaints to the Weed
Commissioner or City Council whenever they observe property that is believed to
be in violation of this chapter. This should be done within the time to prevent
the blooming and maturing of noxious weeds or growths of the unlawful growth of
weeds or growths, if possible.

55.01Â Â Â DEFINITIONS.
Â Â Â The following terms are defined for use in the chapters of this Code of
Ordinances pertaining to animal protection and control.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â â€œAdvertiseâ€ means to present a commercial message in any medium
including but not limited to print, radio, television, sign, display, label,
tag or articulation.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â â€œAnimalâ€ means a nonhuman vertebrate.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 717B.1)
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â â€œAt largeâ€ means off the premises of the owner, unless:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â With reference to a dog, the dog in on a leash, cord, chain, or
similar restraint not more than six feet in length and is under the control of
the person; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The animal is restrained within a motor vehicle; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The animal is housed within a veterinary hospital, kennel, pet shop,
or animal shelter.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â â€œBusinessâ€ means any enterprise relating to any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The sale or offer for sale of goods or services.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A recruitment for employment or membership in an organization.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A solicitation to make an investment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â An amusement or entertainment activity.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â â€œCatâ€ means both male and female animals of the feline species, whether
altered or not.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â â€œDangerous animalâ€ means the following animals:  â€ 
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Castoridae (beavers)
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Chiroptera (bats)
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Didelphidae (opossums)
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Mephitidae (skunks)
Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Mustelidae (such as badgers, ermines, otters, mink, weasels, and
wolverines, but not including ferrets)
Â Â Â Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Procyonidae (such as coatis and raccoons)
Â Â Â Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Scorpiones (scorpions)
Â Â Â Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Viverridae (such as civets, genets and mongooses)
Â Â Â Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Fire ants within the order Hymenoptera
Â Â Â Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Africanized strains of Apis mellifera (African honey bees)
Â Â Â Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Venomous spiders of the families Theridiidae and Loxoscelidae
Â Â Â Â Â Â L.Â Â Â An animal that is the offspring of an animal listed above and any
other animal, including animals that are the offspring of each subsequent
generation.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â â€œDogâ€ means both male and female animals of the canine species, whether
altered or not.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â â€œFairâ€ means any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The annual fair and exposition held by the Iowa State Fair Board
pursuant to Chapter 173 of the Code of Iowa or any fair event conducted by a

Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â An exhibition of agricultural or manufactured products.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An event for operation of amusement rides or devices or concession
booths.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â â€œGameâ€ means a â€œgame of chanceâ€ or â€œgame of skillâ€ as defined in
Section 99B.1 of the Code of Iowa.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â â€œHousingâ€ means any location where an animal is normally kept.
Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â â€œKennel dogâ€ means a dog kept or raised solely for the purpose of sale
and kept under constant restraint.
Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â â€œLeashâ€ means a restraint not more than six feet in length, which is
of sufficient strength to restrain a dog, which leash is held by a person

Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â â€œLivestockâ€ means an animal belonging to the bovine, caprine, equine,

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 717.1)
Â Â Â 14.Â Â Â â€œOwnerâ€ means any person owning, keeping, sheltering or harboring an
animal.
Â Â Â 15.Â Â Â â€œPetâ€ means a living dog, cat, or an animal normally maintained in a

Â Â Â 16.Â Â Â â€œPet shopâ€ means any business established for the purpose of breeding,

Â Â Â 17.Â Â Â â€œVeterinary hospitalâ€ means a public or private establishment
regularly maintained and operated by a licensed veterinarian for the diagnosis

Â Â Â 18.Â Â Â â€œVicious animalâ€ means any animal, except for a dangerous animal per
se, as listed above, which has bitten or clawed a person or persons while
running at large and the attack was unprovoked, or any animal that has
exhibited vicious tendencies in present or past conduct, including such that
said animal:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â While unmuzzled, unleashed, or without supervision of a person whose
verbal commands are obeyed charges or chases in a terrorizing manner with an
apparent attitude of attack any person or animal that is upon a street, alley,
sidewalk or other public or private place; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Has a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack without
provocation or to otherwise threaten the safety of persons or domestic animals;
or
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Has been trained, owned, or harbored for the purpose, primarily, or
in part, of animal fighting; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Has bitten or clawed a person or persons and the attack was
unprovoked, or any animal that has exhibited vicious tendencies in present or
past conduct, including such that said animal has bitten or clawed a person or
person; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Could not be controlled or restrained by the owner at the time of
the attack to prevent the occurrence; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Has attacked any domestic animal or fowl on two separate occasions
within a twelve month period; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Has attacked any person, domestic animal or fowl one time causing
serious injury or death when at large.

55.02Â Â Â ANIMAL NEGLECT.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for a person who impounds or confines, in any place, an
animal, excluding livestock, to fail to supply the animal during confinement
with a sufficient quantity of food or water, or to fail to provide a confined
dog or cat with adequate shelter, or to torture, deprive of necessary
sustenance, mutilate, beat, or kill such animal by any means that causes
unjustified pain, distress or suffering.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 717B.3)
55.03Â Â Â LIVESTOCK NEGLECT.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for a person who impounds or confines livestock in any place
to fail to provide the livestock with care consistent with customary animal
husbandry practices or to deprive the livestock of necessary sustenance or to
injure or destroy livestock by any means that causes pain or suffering in a
manner inconsistent with customary animal husbandry practices.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 717.2)
55.04Â Â Â ABANDONMENT OF CATS AND DOGS.
Â Â Â A person who has ownership or custody of a cat or dog shall not abandon the
cat or dog, except the person may deliver the cat or dog to another person who
will accept ownership and custody or the person may deliver the cat or dog to
an animal shelter or pound.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 717B.8)
55.05Â Â Â LIVESTOCK.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for a person to keep livestock within the City except by
written consent of the Council or except in compliance with the Cityâ€™s zoning
regulations.
55.06Â Â Â AT LARGE PROHIBITED.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for any owner to allow an animal to run at large within the
corporate limits of the City.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any person or persons to permit any animal to be at
large or to stray beyond the property of such person or persons unless such
animal is restrained by leash or confined within a motor vehicle. An
underground electric fence is not considered a restraint.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 1, any animal shall be
deemed at large at any time when the animal is attacking humans, other animals,
or destroying property or is on any public property, except when under
restraint as set forth above. In addition, any female animal in estrus shall be
deemed at large at any time, except:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â When housed in a building completely enclosed; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â When housed in a veterinary hospital or boarding kennel licensed or
registered with the State; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â When on the premises of the owner, provided the area in which such
animal is located is completely enclosed by a fence or other structure; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â When under the control of a person competent to restrain the animal,
either by leash or properly restrained within a motor vehicle.
Â Â Â The fines will be $50.00 for the first offense, $75.00 for the second
offense, or $100.00 for the third offense. An additional $25.00 will be added
for any animal at large not licensed with the City.
55.07Â Â Â NUMBER OF ANIMALS.
Â Â Â No person shall harbor or maintain such number of dogs or cats or
combination thereof to create unhealthful or unsanitary conditions for the
humans or animals occupying the premises, or create any other conditions
constituting a nuisance. If such conditions exist, the Police Chief or Animal
Control Officer designated by the Council is authorized to make an
investigation, and after notice and hearing to the person or persons occupying
or maintaining the residence or premises, or the persons harboring or
maintaining the animals, the Police Chief or designated Animal Control Officer
may order such number of animals to be moved from the residence or premises to
remedy or correct the unhealthful or unsanitary or other conditions
constituting a nuisance. Upon the failure of the person or persons to follow
the orders issued by the Police Chief or designated Animal Control Officer,
appropriate action may be pursued in the courts to either enforce the order
and/or correct the conditions and/or abate the nuisance.
55.08Â Â Â DAMAGE OR INTERFERENCE.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for the owner of an animal to allow or permit such animal to
pass upon the premises of another thereby causing damage to, or interference
with, the premises.
55.09Â Â Â ANNOYANCE OR DISTURBANCE.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for the owner of a dog to allow or permit such dog to cause
serious annoyance or disturbance to any person by frequent and habitual
howling, yelping, barking, or otherwise, or by running after or chasing
persons, bicycles, automobiles or other vehicles.
55.10Â Â Â UNHEALTHFUL OR UNSANITARY CONDITIONS.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â An owner shall keep all structures, pens, coops or yards wherein
animals are confined clean, devoid of vermin and free of odors arising from
feces.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No owner or walker of any animal shall permit the animal to discharge
feces upon any public or private property, other than the property of the owner
of the animal. The owner or walker shall be deemed to permit the animalâ€™s
discharge of feces if the owner does not immediately thereafter take steps to
remove and clean up the feces from the property.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All feces removed as aforesaid shall be placed in an airtight container
and shall be stored in a sanitary manner in an appropriate refuse container,
until it is removed pursuant to refuse collection procedures, or otherwise
disposed of in a sanitary manner.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â An owner may, as an alternative to subsection 3 above, collect the
feces and turn it under the surface of the ownerâ€™s soil in any manner that
prevents odor or collection of vermin.
55.11Â Â Â OWNERâ€™S DUTY.
Â Â Â It is the duty of the owner of any dog, cat, or other animal that has bitten
or attacked a person or any person having knowledge of such bite or attack to
report this act to a local health or law enforcement official. It is the duty
of physicians and veterinarians to report to the local board of health the
existence of any animal known or suspected to be suffering from rabies.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 351.38)
55.12Â Â Â CONFINEMENT.
Â Â Â If a local board of health receives information that an animal has bitten a
person or that a dog or animal is suspected of having rabies, the board shall
order the owner to confine such animal in the manner it directs. If the owner
fails to confine such animal in the manner directed, the animal shall be
apprehended and impounded by such board, and after ten (10) days the board may
humanely destroy the animal. If such animal is returned to its owner, the owner
shall pay the cost of impoundment. This section does not apply if a police
service dog or a horse used by a law enforcement agency and acting in the
performance of its duties has bitten a person.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 351.39)
55.13Â Â Â AT LARGE: IMPOUNDMENT.
Â Â Â Animals found at large in violation of this chapter shall be seized and
impounded, or at the discretion of the peace officer, the owner may be served a
summons to appear before a proper court to answer charges made thereunder.
55.14Â Â Â DISPOSITION OF ANIMALS.
Â Â Â When an animal has been apprehended and impounded, written notice shall be
provided to the owner within two (2) days after impoundment, if the ownerâ€™s
name and current address can reasonably be determined by accessing a tag or
other device that is on or part of the animal. Impounded animals may be
recovered by the owner upon payment of impounding costs, and if an unvaccinated
dog, by having it immediately vaccinated. If the owner fails to redeem the
animal within seven (7) days from the date that the notice is mailed, or if the
owner cannot be located within seven days, the animal shall be disposed of in
accordance with law or destroyed by euthanasia.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 351.37, 351.41)
55.15Â Â Â KEEPING OF DANGEROUS ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
Â Â Â No person shall keep, shelter or harbor any dangerous animal as a pet, or
act as a temporary custodian for such an animal, or keep, shelter or harbor
such animal for any purpose or in any capacity within the City.
55.16Â Â Â KEEPING OF VICIOUS ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
Â Â Â No person shall keep, shelter or harbor for any reason within the City a
vicious animal, with the following exceptions:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Animals under the control of a law enforcement or military agency.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The keeping of guard dogs; however, guard dogs must be kept within a
structure or fixed enclosure at all times, and any guard dog found at large may
be processed as a vicious animal. Any premises guarded by a guard dog shall be
prominently posted with a sign containing the wording â€œGuard Dog,â€ â€œVicious
Dogâ€ or words of similar import, and the owner of such premises shall inform
the Police Chief that a guard dog is on duty at said premises.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No animal shall be deemed vicious as a result of having attacked or
injured who at the time of such attack or injury, was committing a willful
trespass or was committing or attempting to commit other criminal conduct while
on the premises occupied by the owner or keeper of such animal, or was at the
time of the injury or attack, teasing, tormenting, abusing or physically
assaulting the animal.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â No animal shall be deemed vicious as a result of having defended or
protected its owner/keeper from an unjustified attack or physical assault.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â No animal shall be deemed vicious for causing injury or death to
another animal if it was defending itself from an unprovoked attack by such
other animal.
55.17Â Â Â SEIZURE, IMPOUNDMENT AND DISPOSITION OF DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMALS.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In the event that a dangerous animal or vicious animal is found at
large and unattended upon public property, park property, public right-of-way,
or the property of someone other than its owner, thereby creating a hazard to
persons or property, such animal may, in the discretion of the Mayor or the
Police Chief, be destroyed if it cannot be confined or captured. The City shall
be under no duty to attempt the confinement or capture of a dangerous animal or
vicious animal found at large, nor shall it have a duty to notify the owner of
such animal prior to its destruction. If the animal can be confined, it will be
taken to the Cedar Valley Humane Society and held for a period of not less than
ten days, at the ownerâ€™s expense, to be observed for any illness or aggressive
behaviors. At the end of the ten-day period, the case will be reviewed by the
City Council to determine the disposition of the animal.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Upon the complaint of any individual that a person is keeping,
sheltering or harboring a dangerous animal or vicious animal on premises in the
City, the Mayor or Police Chief shall cause the matter to be investigated and
if after investigation, the facts indicate that the person named in the
complaint is keeping, sheltering or harboring a dangerous or vicious animal in
the City, the officer shall order the person named in the complaint to safely
remove such animal from the City or destroy the animal within three (3) days of
the receipt of such an order. Such order shall be contained in a notice to
remove the dangerous or vicious animal, and shall be served personally or by
certified mail. Such order and notice to remove the dangerous or vicious animal
shall not be required where such animal has previously caused serious physical
harm or death to any person or animal, in which case the officer shall cause
the animal to be immediately seized and impounded or destroyed if seizure and
impoundment are not possible without the risk of serious physical harm or death
to any person or animal.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The order to remove a dangerous animal or vicious animal issued by the
officer may be appealed to the Council. In order to appeal such order, written
notice of appeal must be filed with the Clerk within three (3) days after
receipt of the order contained in the notice to remove dangerous or vicious
animal. Failure to file such written notice of appeal shall constitute a waiver
of right to appeal the order of the officer.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The notice of appeal shall state the grounds for such appeal and shall
be delivered personally or by certified mail to the Clerk. The hearing of such
appeal shall be scheduled within seven (7) days of the receipt of notice of
appeal. The hearing may be continued for good cause. After such hearing, the
Council may affirm or reverse the order of the officer. Such determination
shall be contained in a written decision and shall be filed with the Clerk
within three (3) days after the hearing or any continued session thereof.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â If the Council affirms the action of the officer, the Council shall
order in its written decision that the person owning, sheltering, harboring or
keeping such dangerous or vicious animal remove such animal from the City or
destroy it. The decision and order shall immediately be served upon the person
against whom rendered in the same manner as the notice of removal. If the
original order of the officer is not appealed and is not complied with within
three (3) days or the order of the Council after appeal is not complied with
within three (3) days of its issuance, the officer is authorized to seize,
impound or destroy such dangerous animal or vicious animal. Failure to comply
with an order of the officer issued pursuant to this chapter and not appealed,
or of the Council after appeal constitutes a simple misdemeanor.
55.18Â Â Â PET AWARDS PROHIBITED.
(Code of Iowa, Ch. 717E)
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Prohibition. It is unlawful for any person to award a pet or advertise
that a pet may be awarded as any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A prize for participating in a game.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A prize for participating in a fair.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An inducement or condition for visiting a place of business or
attending an event sponsored by a business.
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â An inducement or condition for executing a contract that includes
provisions unrelated to the ownership, care or disposition of the pet.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Exceptions. This section does not apply to any of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A pet shop licensed pursuant to Section 162.5 of the Code of Iowa if
the award of a pet is provided in connection with the sale of a pet on the
premises of the pet shop.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Youth programs associated with 4-H Clubs; Future Farmers of America;
the Izaak Walton League of America; or organizations associated with outdoor
recreation, hunting or fishing, including but not limited to the Iowa
Sportsmenâ€™s Federation.
55.19Â Â Â FIELD DRESSING OF WILD ANIMALS.
Â Â Â Any person who kills an animal while hunting shall take all precautionary
measures to avoid field dressing (defined as the process of removing blood and
internal organs from an animal or fowl carcass) and hanging the animal or fowl
in a public or conspicuous place or a place visible to the general public.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Field dressing on City property is not allowed.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any individual who field dresses an animal or fowl carcass within the
City is required to containerize and remove all blood and internal organs from
within the City. No blood or internal organs resulting from field dressing an
animal or fowl shall be buried, burned, or otherwise disposed of within the
City, nor shall any blood or internal organs be placed in trash containers for
collection by the City.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The transportation of a carcass along any public right-of-way is
prohibited, unless it is covered or hidden from public view.
Â Â Â Any person, entity, or group of individuals who shall perform an act in
violation of this section shall have committed a simple misdemeanor.

56.01Â Â Â LICENSE REQUIRED.
Â Â Â Every owner of a dog over the age of four (4) months shall procure a dog
license from the Clerk on or before the first day of January of each year. Dogs
whose owners are nonresidents temporarily within the City for a period of less
than 30 days, dogs brought into the City for the purpose of participating in an
animal show, Seeing Eye Â® dogs trained to assist blind persons, or kennel dogs
need not be licensed. Any new dog owner or any owner who becomes a resident of
the City after January 1 of any year shall obtain a license for said dog within
30 days after becoming a resident of the City without penalty.
56.02Â Â Â LICENSE FEES.
Â Â Â The license fee shall be as established by resolution of the Council. No
license fee shall be refunded.
56.03Â Â Â EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
Â Â Â All licenses shall expire on December 31 st of the third year after
issuance.
56.04Â Â Â LICENSE ISSUED.
Â Â Â Upon payment of the license fee as set by resolution, the Clerk shall issue
to the owner a license, which shall contain the name of the owner, the ownerâ€™s
place of residence, and a description of the dog, including breed, sex, color,
markings and name, if any, of the animal. The Clerk shall keep a duplicate of
each license issued as a public record.
56.05Â Â Â LICENSE TAGS.
Â Â Â Upon issuance of the license, the Clerk shall deliver to the owner a license
tag in the form prescribed by the Council, which license tag shall bear the
number of the license. The license tag shall be worn by the dog for which the
license is issued. The license tag shall be securely fastened to a collar or
harness which shall be worn by the dog during the term of the license. A
license issued for one dog shall not be transferable to another dog. Any dog
found running at large without the license tag attached to its collar or
harness shall be deemed unlicensed.
56.06Â Â Â TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
Â Â Â When the permanent ownership of a dog is transferred, the license may be
transferred by the Clerk by notation on the license record, giving name and
address of the new owner. Upon transfer of a licensed dog into the City, the
owner shall surrender the original license tag to the Clerk. The Clerk shall
preserve the surrendered tag and, without a license fee, issue a new license
tag.
56.07Â Â Â LOST OR DESTROYED LICENSES.
Â Â Â Upon the filing of an affidavit that the license tag has been lost or
destroyed, the owner may obtain another tag on the payment of 50 cents. The
Clerk shall enter in the license record the new number assigned.
56.08Â Â Â LICENSE RECORDS.
Â Â Â The Clerk shall keep a book to be known as the record of licenses; such
record shall show:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The serial number and date of each application for a license.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The description of the dog as specified in the application, together
with the name of the owner of the dog.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The date when each license tag is issued and the serial number of each
tag, the date of the most recent rabies vaccination.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The amount of all fees, licenses, penalties and costs paid to the
Clerk.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Such other data as may be required by law.
56.09Â Â Â IMMUNIZATION REQUIRED.
Â Â Â All dogs four months old or over shall be vaccinated against rabies. Before
a license is issued, the owner shall furnish a veterinarianâ€™s certificate
showing that the dog for which the license is sought has been vaccinated
against rabies, and that the vaccination does not expire within six months from
the effective date of the dog license. A tag showing evidence of proper
vaccination shall at all times be worn by the dog when it is not contained.
56.10Â Â Â KENNEL DOGS.
Â Â Â Dogs kept in State or Federally licensed kennels, which are kept or raised
solely for the bona fide purpose of sale and which are kept under constant
restraint, are not subject to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ch. 56 â€“ Ord. 03-2014 â€“ Jul. 15 Supp.)
CHAPTER 57

57.01 Definitions 57.02 Permit Required

57.01Â Â Â DEFINITIONS.
Â Â Â The following terms are defined for use in the chapters of this Code of
Ordinances pertaining to Livestock.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â "Chicken" shall mean a member of the subspecies Gallus domesticus, a
domesticated fowl.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â "Duck" shall mean a member of the subspecies Anatidae Anseriformes, a
fowl.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â "Urban Chicken" shall mean a chicken kept on a permitted tract of land
pursuant to a permit issued under this Chapter.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â "Permitting Officer" shall mean the City Manager or designee.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â "Tract of land" shall mean a property or a zoned lot that has one
single family dwelling located on that property or zoned lot.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â "Single Family Dwelling" shall mean any building that contains only one
dwelling unit used, intended, rented, leased, let or hired to be occupied for
living purposes.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â "Permitted tract of land" shall mean the tract of land as identified by
the application upon which a permit is granted for keeping chickens pursuant to
this Chapter.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â "Permittee" shall mean an applicant who has been granted a permit to
raise, harbor or keep chickens pursuant to this Chapter.
57.02Â Â Â PERMIT REQUIRED.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for a person to keep livestock within the City, except in
compliance with the Cityâ€™s zoning regulations.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the keeping of domestic
chickens or ducks shall be permitted in all residential zoning districts so
long as such keeping is in compliance with this subsection and all other
applicable City ordinances unless, despite compliance with the following, the
presence of any particular chickens endanger the health, safety, peace, quiet,
comfort, enjoyment of, or otherwise become a public nuisance to nearby
residents or occupants or places of business:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Chickens or Ducks must be confined in a coop or fowl house not less
than 18 inches in height or, in the alternative, within a fenced pen area.
Chickens or Ducks must be kept within the coop, the fowl house, or the fenced
pen area at all times unless removed for a temporary time for the safety of the
chicken or duck.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The coop, the fowl house, or the fenced pen area must be of such a
design to be reasonably expected to prevent entry by dogs, cats, or other
animals and shall be completely enclosed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The coop or fowl house must be used for chickens only and must be
well ventilated.
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The coop, the fowl house, or the fenced pen area shall have a
minimum of four (4) square feet of floor area for each chicken but shall not be
any larger than twelve (12) square feet of area for each chicken. The coop,
fowl house, or fenced pen area shall be a minimum of seven (7) feet from any
property line. In the event a zoning or other ordinance requires a greater
distance, the more restrictive regulations shall apply.
Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any coop, fowl house, or fenced pen area must be well drained so
there is no accumulation of moisture.
Â Â Â Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Any coop, fowl house, or fenced pen area shall be kept clean,
sanitary and free from accumulation of chicken or duck excrement and
objectionable odors. All droppings and body excretions shall be either placed
in fly-proof containers and double-bagged in plastic bags or, in the
alternative, used as fertilizer on the same property or, with the owner's
permission, on other property within the City, so long as the droppings and
body excretions are spread and incorporated into the soil within twenty four
(24) hours.
Â Â Â Â Â Â G.Â Â Â In addition to the coop, fowl house, or fenced pen area, the owner's
property shall be sufficiently fenced to confine chickens or ducks to the
property and prevent chickens or ducks from entering upon any adjacent
property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â H.Â Â Â All feed shall be stored in rodent-proof containers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â I.Â Â Â No more than six (6) chickens or ducks shall be kept or maintained
per property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â J.Â Â Â All such chickens must be hens; no roosters are permitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â K.Â Â Â The City shall not be liable for injury or death of chickens or
ducks caused by dogs, cats, or other animals, domestic or wild, whether such
animals are licensed by the City or not. Further, injury or death of a chicken
or duck caused by an animal is not, in and of itself, sufficient grounds for
the City to determine that the animal is a vicious animal pursuant to Chapter
55 of this Code of Ordinances. Any dead chicken or duck, not caused by
slaughtering, shall be disposed of immediately upon discovering in a manner so
as to not cause a nuisance pursuant to Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances.
Â Â Â Â Â Â L.Â Â Â Any slaughter of chickens or ducks not regulated by state law or
otherwise forbidden or regulated shall be done only in a humane and sanitary
manner and shall not be done open to the view of any public area or adjacent
property owned by another.
Â Â Â Â Â Â M.Â Â Â An owner or possessor of animals on property that is newly annexed
has ninety (90) days from the date of annexation to bring the property into
compliance required by this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â N.Â Â Â A violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction as provided
in Chapter 3 of this Code of Ordinances.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No person shall keep any chickens or ducks unless they possess a City
of Lisbon permit issued by the City Administrator. A permit will not be issued
until the applicant has submitted a completed application on forms provided by
the Permitting Officer, either on line or in paper form, and paying all fees
required by this Chapter. The requirements to the receipt of a permit include:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All requirements of this Chapter are met;
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All fees, as may be provided for from time to time by City Council
resolution, for the permit are paid in full;
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All judgements in the City's favor and against the applicant have
been paid in full;
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The tract of land to be permitted shall contain only one single
family dwelling occupied and used as such by the permittee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The applicant has provided notice to the residents of all
immediately adjacent dwellings of the applicant's intent to obtain a permit'
and
Â Â Â Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The applicant has successfully completed an approved class in
raising chickens in an urban setting. The Permitting Officer shall maintain a
current list of such approved classes.
The fee for such permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00). Permits will be granted
for one (1) year valid from January 1 through December 31. Permits may be
purchased at any time during the year but will be valid only through December
31.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The permit may be suspended or revoked by the City Administrator upon
hearing and finding evidence that the permittee has violated the conditions of
the permit and listed in Section 57.02. All chickens or ducks must be removed
upon revocation of the permit. There will be no refund of the permit fee.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â By the granting of the permit to raise chickens or ducks and the
application thereof, the permittee authorizes that the City or its agents have
the right to go onto permittee's property any time for the limited purpose of
inspection of the premises to ensure that all applicable conditions have been
met.
(Ch. 57 - Ord. 5-2020 - Aug. 21 Supp.)

60.01Â Â Â TITLE.
Â Â Â Chapters 60 through 70 of this Code of Ordinances may be known and cited as
the â€œLisbon Traffic Code.â€
60.02Â Â Â DEFINITIONS.
Â Â Â Where words and phrases used in the Traffic Code are defined by State law,
such definitions apply to their use in said Traffic Code and are adopted by
reference. Those definitions so adopted that need further definition or are
reiterated, and other words and phrases used herein, have the following
meanings:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.1)
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â â€œBusiness Districtâ€ means the territory contiguous to and including a
highway when fifty percent (50%) or more of the frontage thereon for a distance
of three hundred (300) feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for
business.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â â€œParkâ€ or â€œparkingâ€ means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied
or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually
engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â â€œPeace officerâ€ means every officer authorized to direct or regulate
traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â â€œResidence districtâ€ means the territory contiguous to and including a
highway not comprising a business, suburban or school district, where forty
percent (40%) or more of the frontage on such a highway for a distance of three
hundred (300) feet or more is occupied by dwellings or by dwellings and
buildings in use for business.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â â€œSchool districtâ€ means the territory contiguous to and including a
highway for a distance of two hundred (200) feet in either direction from a
schoolhouse.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â â€œStandâ€ or â€œstandingâ€ means the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied
or not, otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in
receiving or discharging passengers.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â â€œStopâ€ means when required, the complete cessation of movement.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â â€œStopâ€ or â€œstoppingâ€ means when prohibited, any halting of a vehicle,
even momentarily, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a peace
officer or traffic control sign or signal.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â â€œSuburban districtâ€ means all other parts of the City not included in
the business, school, or residence districts.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â â€œTraffic control deviceâ€ means all signs, signals, markings, and
devices not inconsistent with this chapter, lawfully placed or erected for the
purpose of regulating, warning, or guiding traffic.
Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â â€œVehicleâ€ means every device in, upon, or by which any person or
property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, street, or
alley.
60.03Â Â Â ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT.
Â Â Â Provisions of this Traffic Code and State law relating to motor vehicles and
law of the road are enforced by the Police Chief.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
60.04Â Â Â POWER TO DIRECT TRAFFIC.
Â Â Â A peace officer or, in the absence of a peace officer, any officer of the
Fire Department when at the scene of a fire, is authorized to direct all
traffic by voice, hand, or signal in conformance with traffic laws. In the
event of an emergency, traffic may be directed as conditions require,
notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 102.4 & 321.236[2])
60.05Â Â Â TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS: REPORTS.
Â Â Â The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident within the limits of the
City shall file a report as and when required by the Iowa Department of
Transportation. A copy of this report shall be filed with the City for the
confidential use of peace officers and shall be subject to the provisions of
Section 321.271 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.273)
60.06Â Â Â PEACE OFFICERâ€™S AUTHORITY.
Â Â Â A peace officer is authorized to stop a vehicle to require exhibition of the
driverâ€™s license of the driver, to serve a summons or memorandum of traffic
violation, to inspect the condition of the vehicle, to inspect the vehicle with
reference to size, weight, cargo, log book, bills of lading or other manifest
of employment, tires and safety equipment, or to inspect the registration
certificate, the compensation certificate, travel order, or permit of such
vehicle. A peace officer having probable cause to stop a vehicle may require
exhibition of the proof of financial liability coverage card issued for the
vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.492)
60.07Â Â Â OBEDIENCE TO PEACE OFFICERS.
Â Â Â No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or
direction of any peace officer invested by law with authority to direct,
control or regulate traffic.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.229)
60.08Â Â Â PARADES REGULATED.
Â Â Â No person shall conduct or cause any parade on any street except as provided
herein:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â â€œParadeâ€ Defined. â€œParadeâ€ means any march or procession of persons or
vehicles organized for marching or moving on the streets in an organized
fashion or manner or any march or procession of persons or vehicles represented
or advertised to the public as a parade.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Permission Required. No parade shall be conducted without first
obtaining a permission from the Council. The person organizing or sponsoring
the parade shall provide information concerning the time and date for the
parade and the streets or general route therefor, and any permission given to
such person includes all participants in the parade, provided they have been
invited to participate.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Parade Not A Street Obstruction. Any parade for which permission has
been given and the persons lawfully participating therein shall not be deemed
an obstruction of the streets, notwithstanding the provisions of any other
ordinance to the contrary.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Control By Peace Officers and Firefighters. Persons participating in
any parade shall at all times be subject to the lawful orders and directions in
the performance of their duties of law enforcement personnel and members of the
Fire Department.
CHAPTER 61
TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES
Â 
61.01 Installation  61.04 Standards
61.02 Crosswalks    61.05 Compliance
61.03 Traffic Lanes

61.01Â Â Â INSTALLATION.
Â Â Â The Police Chief shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic control
devices when and as required under this Traffic Code or under State law or
emergency or temporary traffic control devices for the duration of an emergency
or temporary condition as traffic conditions may require to regulate, guide or
warn traffic. The Police Chief shall keep a record of all such traffic control
devices.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.255)
61.02Â Â Â CROSSWALKS.
Â Â Â The Police Chief is hereby authorized, subject to approval of the Council by
resolution, to designate and maintain crosswalks by appropriate traffic control
devices at intersections where, due to traffic conditions, there is particular
danger to pedestrians crossing the street or roadway, and at such other places
as traffic conditions require.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4] & 321.255)
61.03Â Â Â TRAFFIC LANES.
Â Â Â The Police Chief is hereby authorized to mark lanes for traffic on street
pavements at such places as traffic conditions require, consistent with this
Traffic Code. Where such traffic lanes have been marked, it is unlawful for the
operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicle within the
boundaries of any such lane except when lawfully passing another vehicle or
preparatory to making a lawful turning movement.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4] & 321.255)
61.04Â Â Â STANDARDS.
Â Â Â Traffic control devices shall comply with standards established by The
Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.255)
61.05Â Â Â COMPLIANCE.
Â Â Â No driver of a vehicle shall disobey the instructions of any official
traffic control device placed in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter, unless at the time otherwise directed by a peace officer, subject to
the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle under
Section 321.231 of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.256)

62.02Â Â Â PLAY STREETS DESIGNATED.
Â Â Â The Police Chief shall have authority to declare any street or part thereof
a play street and cause to be placed appropriate signs or devices in the
roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. Whenever authorized signs
are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person
shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of
vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and
then any said driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such
street or portion thereof.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.255)
62.03Â Â Â VEHICLES ON SIDEWALKS.
Â Â Â The driver of a vehicle shall not drive upon or within any sidewalk area
except at a driveway.
62.04Â Â Â CLINGING TO VEHICLE.
Â Â Â No person shall drive a motor vehicle on the streets of the City unless all
passengers of said vehicle are inside the vehicle in the place intended for
their accommodation. No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates,
in-line skates, sled, or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself or
herself to any vehicle upon a roadway.
62.05Â Â Â QUIET ZONES.
Â Â Â Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a quiet zone, no person
operating a motor vehicle within any such zone shall sound the horn or other
warning device of such vehicle except in an emergency.
62.06Â Â Â OBSTRUCTING VIEW AT INTERSECTIONS.
Â Â Â It is unlawful to allow any tree, hedge, billboard, or other object to
obstruct the view of an intersection by preventing persons from having a clear
view of traffic approaching the intersection from cross streets. Any such
obstruction is deemed a nuisance and in addition to the standard penalty may be
abated in the manner provided by
Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances.
62.07Â Â Â MILLING.
Â Â Â It is unlawful to drive or operate a vehicle, either singly or with others,
in any processional milling or repeated movement over any street to the
interference with normal traffic use, or to the annoyance or offense of any
person.
62.08Â Â Â ADMINISTRATIVE FEE FOR TOWING VEHICLES.
Â Â Â In addition to any penalty provided by law, the City may impose an
administrative fee for each instance of towing a vehicle pursuant to this Code
of Ordinances. The fee imposed shall be in an amount set by the Police
Department and the City Council by resolution, and except as otherwise provided
must be paid prior to release of the vehicle from the Cityâ€™s custody.

63.01Â Â Â GENERAL.
Â Â Â Every driver of a motor vehicle on a street shall drive the same at a
careful and prudent speed not greater than nor less than is reasonable and
proper, having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of the street and
of any other conditions then existing, and no person shall drive a vehicle on
any street at a speed greater than will permit said driver to bring it to a
stop within the assured clear distance ahead, such driver having the right to
assume, however, that all persons using said street will observe the law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.285)
63.02Â Â Â STATE CODE SPEED LIMITS.
Â Â Â The following speed limits are established in Section 321.285 of the Code of
Iowa and any speed in excess thereof is unlawful unless specifically designated
otherwise in this chapter as a special speed zone.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Business District â€“ twenty (20) miles per hour.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Residence or School District â€“ twenty-five (25) miles per hour.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Suburban District â€“ forty-five (45) miles per hour.
63.03Â Â Â PARKS, CEMETERIES, AND PARKING LOTS.
Â Â Â A speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour in any public park,
cemetery, or parking lot, unless specifically designated otherwise in this
chapter, is unlawful.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[5])
63.04Â Â Â SPECIAL SPEED ZONES.
Â Â Â In accordance with requirements of the Iowa Department of Transportation, or
whenever the Council shall determine upon the basis of an engineering and
traffic investigation that any speed limit listed in Section 63.02 is greater
or less than is reasonable or safe under the conditions found to exist at any
intersection or other place or upon any part of the City street system, the
Council shall determine and adopt by ordinance such higher or lower speed limit
as it deems reasonable and safe at such location. The following special speed
zones have been established:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.290)
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Special 25 MPH Speed Zones. A speed in excess of 25 miles per hour is
unlawful on any of the following designated streets or parts thereof.
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â On Lisbon Road (Main Street - Old Highway 30) from the west
corporate limits to Eby Street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â On Cemetery Road from Washington Street to the east corporate
limits.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Special 30 MPH Speed Zones. A speed in excess of 30 miles per hour is
unlawful on any of the following designated streets or parts thereof.
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â On Country Club Drive between the south corporate limits and the
west corporate limits.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Special 35 MPH Speed Zones. A speed in excess of 35 miles per hour is
unlawful on any of the following designated streets or parts thereof.
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â On Washington Street between Cemetery Road and the south corporate

Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â On Washington Street from a point 800 feet south of the north

850 feet north of the railroad tracks.
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â On Business 30 between Station 784+08 and Station 812+74.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Special 45 MPH Speed Zones. A speed in excess of 45 miles per hour is

Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â On Washington Street from the north corporate limits southbound to a

Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â On Business 30 between Station 812+74 and Station 819+39 (east
corporate limits).
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â On Business 30 between Station 746+21 (west corporate limits) and
Station 784+00.
(Ord. 02-2021 - Aug. 21 Supp.)
63.05Â Â Â MINIMUM SPEED.
Â Â Â A person shall not drive a motor vehicle at such a slow speed as to impede
or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic, except when reduced
speed is necessary for safe operation, or in compliance with law.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.294)
(Ord. 02-2021 - Aug. 21 Supp.)
CHAPTER 64
TURNING REGULATIONS
Â 
64.01 Turning at Intersections 64.03 Left Turn for Parking
64.02 U-Turns
Â 
64.01Â Â Â TURNING AT INTERSECTIONS.
Â Â Â The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall do so as
follows:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.311)
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as
close as practical to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right
half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof and after entering the
intersection the left turn shall be made so as to depart from the intersection
to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Approach for a left turn from a two-way street into a one-way street
shall be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the
centerline thereof and by passing to the right of such centerline where it
enters the intersection. A left turn from a one-way street into a two-way
street shall be made by passing to the right of the centerline of the street
being entered upon leaving the intersection.
The Police Chief may cause markers, buttons or signs to be placed within or
adjacent to intersections and thereby require and direct, as traffic conditions
require, that a different course from that specified above be traveled by
vehicles turning at intersections, and when markers, buttons or signs are so
placed, no driver of a vehicle shall turn a vehicle at an intersection other
than as directed and required by such markers, buttons or signs.
64.02Â Â Â U-TURNS.
Â Â Â It is unlawful for a driver to make a U-turn except at an intersection;
however, U-turns are prohibited within the Business District and at
intersections where there are automatic traffic signals.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[9])
64.03Â Â Â LEFT TURN FOR PARKING.
Â Â Â No person shall make a left hand turn, crossing the centerline of the
street, for the purpose of parking on said street.

65.07Â Â Â STOP BEFORE CROSSING SIDEWALK.
Â Â Â The driver of a vehicle emerging from a private roadway, alley, driveway, or

vehicle.

or within any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.327)
CHAPTER 66

Â

66.01Â Â Â TEMPORARY EMBARGO.
Â Â Â If the Council declares an embargo when it appears by reason of
deterioration, rain, snow or other climatic conditions that certain streets
will be seriously damaged or destroyed by vehicles weighing in excess of an
amount specified by the signs, no such vehicles shall be operated on streets so
designated by such signs.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.471 & 472)
66.02Â Â Â PERMITS FOR EXCESS SIZE AND WEIGHT.
Â Â Â The Police Chief may, upon application and good cause being shown, issue a
special permit in writing authorizing the applicant to operate or move a
vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight or load exceeding the
maximum specified by State law or the City over those streets or bridges named
in the permit which are under the jurisdiction of the City and for which the
City is responsible for maintenance.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.473 & 321E.1)
66.03Â Â Â TRUCK ROUTE.
Â Â Â Truck route regulations are established as follows:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Truck Routes Designated. Every motor vehicle weighing more than eight
tons or more, when loaded or empty, having no fixed terminal within the City or
making no scheduled or definite stops within the City for the purpose of
loading or unloading shall travel over or upon the following streets within the
City and none other:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.473)
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Main Street between the east corporate limits and the west corporate
limits.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Washington Street between the south corporate limits and the north
corporate limits.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Deliveries Off Truck Route. Any motor vehicle weighing eight tons or
more, when loaded or empty, having a fixed terminal, making a scheduled or
definite stop within the City for the purpose of loading or unloading shall
proceed over or upon the designated routes set out in this section to the
nearest point of its scheduled or definite stop and shall proceed thereto, load
or unload, and return by the most direct route to its point of departure from
said designated route.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.473)
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Employerâ€™s Responsibility. The owner or any other person employing or
otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle shall not require or knowingly

(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.473)

69.01Â Â Â PARK ADJACENT TO CURB.
Â Â Â No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel
with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement
and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of
the curb or edge of the roadway except as hereinafter provided in the case of
angle parking and vehicles parked on the left-hand side of one-way streets.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.361)
69.02Â Â Â PARK ADJACENT TO CURB â€“ ONE-WAY STREET.
Â Â Â No person shall stand or park a vehicle on the left-hand side of a one-way
street other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction
of lawful traffic movement and with the left-hand wheels of the vehicle within
eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway except as hereinafter
provided in the case of angle parking.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.361)
69.03Â Â Â ANGLE PARKING.
Â Â Â Angle or diagonal parking is permitted only in the following locations:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.361)
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Main Street on both sides between Jackson Street and Walnut Street.
69.04Â Â Â ANGLE PARKING â€“ MANNER.
Â Â Â Upon those streets or portions of streets that have been signed or marked
for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at an
angle to the curb or edge of the roadway or in the center of the roadway as
indicated by such signs and markings. No part of any vehicle or the load
thereon, when said vehicle is parked within a diagonal parking district, shall
extend into the roadway more than a distance of sixteen (16) feet when measured
at right angles to the adjacent curb or edge of roadway.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.361)
69.05Â Â Â PARKING FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES ILLEGAL.
Â Â Â No person shall park a vehicle upon public property for more than 48 hours,
unless otherwise limited under the provisions of this chapter, or for any of
the following principal purposes:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Sale. Displaying such vehicle for sale;
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Repairing. For lubricating, repairing or for commercial washing of such
vehicle except such repairs as are necessitated by an emergency;
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Advertising. Displaying advertising;
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Merchandise Sales. Selling merchandise from such vehicle except in a
duly established market place or when so authorized or licensed under this Code
of Ordinances.
69.06Â Â Â PARKING PROHIBITED.
Â Â Â No one shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a peace
officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Crosswalk. On a crosswalk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[5])
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Center Parkway. On the center parkway or dividing area of any divided
street.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Mailboxes. Within twenty (20) feet on either side of a mailbox that is
so placed and so equipped as to permit the depositing of mail from vehicles on
the roadway.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Sidewalks. On or across a sidewalk.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[1])
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Driveway. In front of a public or private driveway.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[2])
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Intersection. Within an intersection or within ten (10) feet of an
intersection of any street or alley.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[3])
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Fire Hydrant. Within five (5) feet of a fire hydrant.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[4])
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Stop Sign or Signal. Within fifteen (15) feet upon the approach to any
flashing beacon, stop or yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the
side of a roadway.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[6])
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Railroad Crossing. Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a
railroad crossing, except when parked parallel with such rail and not
exhibiting a red light.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[8])
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Fire Station. Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any
fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire

posted.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[9])
Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Excavations. Alongside or opposite any street excavation or
obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[10])
Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â Double Parking. On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked
at the edge or curb of a street.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[11])
Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â Hazardous Locations. When, because of restricted visibility or when
standing or parked vehicles would constitute a hazard to moving traffic, or

painted with a yellow color and erect no parking or standing signs.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[13])
Â Â Â 14.Â Â Â Churches, Nursing Homes and Other Buildings. A space of fifty (50)
feet is hereby reserved at the side of the street in front of any theatre,
auditorium, hotel having more than twenty-five (25) sleeping rooms, hospital,
nursing home, taxicab stand, bus depot, church, or other building where large
assemblages of people are being held, within which space, when clearly marked
as such, no motor vehicle shall be left standing, parked or stopped except in
taking on or discharging passengers or freight, and then only for such length
of time as is necessary for such purpose.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.360)
Â Â Â 15.Â Â Â Alleys. No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a
manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet
of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no
person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position
as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. The provisions of
this subsection do not apply to a vehicle parked in any alley that is eighteen
(18) feet wide or less, provided that said vehicle is parked to deliver goods
or services.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 16.Â Â Â Ramps. In front of a curb cut or ramp which is located on public or
private property in a manner which blocks access to the curb cut or ramp.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.358[15])
Â Â Â 17.Â Â Â Area Between Lot Line and Curb Line. That area of the public way not
covered by sidewalk and lying between the lot line and the curb line, where
curbing has been installed.
Â Â Â 18.Â Â Â In More Than One Space. In any designated parking space so that any
part of the vehicle occupies more than one such space or protrudes beyond the
markings designating such space.

69.11Â Â Â SNOW REMOVAL.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide procedures for
ordering the location of vehicles parked on City streets so as not to impede
the progress of snow removal equipment endeavoring to clear the streets of snow
and to provide for the tow-away of vehicles so stopped, standing, or parked as
to constitute safety hazards by impeding the passage of vehicles on the streets
or the removal of unsafe accumulations of snow and ice.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Snow Routes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles upon streets designated
as snow routes, except as required at intersections or otherwise to avoid
collision, is prohibited when, by public announcement, a Snow Emergency has
been placed in effect. Parking on snow routes is prohibited from the time the
snow ordinance goes into effect until the snow removal operations have been
completed for the entire width of said streets.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In order to remove snow piles left after ordinary plowing
operations, a Snow Emergency may, by public announcement, be placed in effect
for certain portions of the City, as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â Downtown. When it is announced that a Snow Emergency is being
placed in effect for the downtown area, the following portions of the streets
are included: Main Street from Walnut Street to Jackson Street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â South Jackson Street. When it is announced that a Snow Emergency
is being placed in effect for the South Jackson Street area, the following
portions of the street are included: South Jackson Street from East Main to
East South Street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â North Washington. When it is announced that a Snow Emergency is
being placed in effect for the North Washington Street area, the following
portions of the street are included: North Washington Street from East Main to
East Market Street.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â When a Snow Emergency has been placed in effect pursuant to this
subsection, parking on streets in the announced areas shall be prohibited from
2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Snow Routes Designated.
Street Name Location

                        with Washington Street

Â 
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Temporary Tow-Away Zones for Snow Removal. After especially heavy snow
accumulations, the Police Chief may post other streets with snow removal, tow-
away notice signs, and cause the towing of vehicles parked contrary to such
notice posted for more than 12 hours when such is deemed necessary to enable
City crews to clear out snow from areas that had numerous parked cars or which
for some other reason could not be effectively cleared of snow by ordinary snow
plowing operations, so as to obviate the occurrence or continuance of a special
hazard caused by the said condition.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Violations; Towing. Vehicles parked in violation of any provision of
this section shall be cited for said violation and, to obviate the safety
hazards caused by incomplete snow removal, be summarily towed on orders of a
police officer to some place where the vehicle may be lawfully parked. The
costs of such towing shall be assessed to and paid by the operator or
registered owner of the vehicle.
(Ord. 01-2021 - Aug. 21 Supp.)

70.01Â Â Â ARREST OR CITATION.
Â Â Â Whenever a peace officer has reasonable cause to believe that a person has
violated any provision of the Traffic Code, such officer may:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Immediate Arrest. Immediately arrest such person and take such person
before a local magistrate, or
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Issue Citation. Without arresting the person, prepare a combined
traffic citation and complaint as adopted by the Iowa Commissioner of Public
Safety, or issue a uniform citation and complaint utilizing a State-approved
computerized device.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 805.6 & 321.485)
(Ord. 01-2023- Jul. 23 Supp.)
70.02Â Â Â SCHEDULED VIOLATIONS.
Â Â Â For violations of the Traffic Code that are designated by Section 805.8A of
the Code of Iowa to be scheduled violations, the scheduled fine for each of
those violations shall be as specified in Section 805.8A of the Code of Iowa.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 805.8 & 805.8A)
70.03Â Â Â PARKING VIOLATIONS: ALTERNATE.
Â Â Â Uncontested violations of parking restrictions imposed by this Code of
Ordinances shall be charged upon a simple notice of a fine payable at the
office of the City Clerk. The simple notice of a fine shall be in the amount of
$25.00 for all violations except improper use of a persons with disabilities
parking permit. If such fine is not paid within thirty (30) days, it shall be
increased by five dollars ($5.00). The simple notice of a fine for improper use
of a persons with disabilities parking permit is one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1b] & 321L.4[2])
70.04Â Â Â PARKING VIOLATIONS: VEHICLE UNATTENDED.
Â Â Â When a vehicle is parked in violation of any provision of the Traffic Code,
and the driver is not present, the notice of fine or citation as herein
provided shall be attached to the vehicle in a conspicuous place.
70.05Â Â Â PRESUMPTION IN REFERENCE TO ILLEGAL PARKING.
Â Â Â In any proceeding charging a standing or parking violation, a prima facie
presumption that the registered owner was the person who parked or placed such
vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation
occurred shall be raised by proof that:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Described Vehicle. The particular vehicle described in the information
was parked in violation of the Traffic Code, and
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Registered Owner. The defendant named in the information was the
registered owner at the time in question.
70.06Â Â Â IMPOUNDING VEHICLES.
Â Â Â A peace officer is hereby authorized to remove, or cause to be removed, a
vehicle from a street, public alley, public parking lot or highway to the
nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or
maintained by the City, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Disabled Vehicle. When a vehicle is so disabled as to constitute an
obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are
by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to
provide for its custody or removal.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Illegally Parked Vehicle. When any vehicle is left unattended and is so
illegally parked as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the
normal movement of traffic.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Snow Removal. When any vehicle is left parked in violation of a ban on
parking during a snow removal operations.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Parked Over Limited Time Period. When any vehicle is left parked for a
continuous period in violation of any limited parking time. If the owner can be
located, the owner shall be given an opportunity to remove the vehicle.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 321.236[1])
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Failure to Pay Fines. When any vehicle has accumulated two or more
unpaid parking fines.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Costs. In addition to the standard penalties provided, the owner or
driver of any vehicle impounded for the violations of any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be required to pay the reasonable cost of towing and
storage.
(Ord. 05-2017- Dec. 17 Supp.)
