170.08Â Â Â PLATS REQUIRED.
Â Â Â In order to secure approval of a proposed subdivision, the owner and
subdivider shall submit to the City plats and other information as required by
this chapter. The owner and subdivider of any major subdivision shall comply
with the requirements for a preliminary plat and the requirements for a final
plat. The owner and subdivider of a minor subdivision may elect to omit the
submission of a preliminary plat as per the requirements of Section
170.04 of this chapter.
170.09Â Â Â PLATS TO CONFORM TO COMPREHENSIVE PLAN, APPLICABLE RULES, AND
REGULATIONS.
Â Â Â The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location of all
streets and the general nature and extent of the lots and uses proposed shall
conform to the Comprehensive Plan of the City, provided such plan has been
adopted by the City, and shall conform to such other plans, including (but not
limited to) a Major Street Plan, a Sanitary Sewer System Plan, or a Parks and
Open Space Plan, provided such plans have been adopted by the City.
170.10Â Â Â PRE-APPLICATION CONFERENCE.
Â Â Â Whenever a subdivision located within the platting jurisdiction of the City
is proposed, the owner and subdivider shall schedule a pre-application
conference with the City Administrator. The conference should be attended by
the City Administrator and such other City or Utility representatives as is
deemed desirable, and by the owner and engineer and/or planner, as deemed
desirable.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The purpose of such conference shall be to acquaint the City with the
proposed subdivision, and to acquaint the subdivider with the requirements,
procedures, and any special problems relating to the proposed subdivision.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â For the pre-application conference, the subdivider shall provide a map
or sketch showing the location of the subdivision, the general location of any
proposed streets and other improvements, and the general layout and arrangement
of intended land uses in relation to the surrounding area.
170.11Â Â Â PRESENTATION TO COMMISSION OR COUNCIL.
Â Â Â The subdivider may present the sketch plan to the Commission and Council for
review, prior to incurring significant costs preparing the preliminary or final
plat.
170.12Â Â Â REQUIREMENTS OF THE PRELIMINARY PLAT.
Â Â Â The subdivider shall prepare a preliminary plat in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter and shall file with the Clerk an application in
triplicate for the tentative approval of the plat. The subdivider shall prepare
and file with the City Clerk 20 copies of the preliminary plat, drawn at a
scale of one inch equals 100 feet (1 = 100 ) or larger. Sheet size shall not
exceed 24 inches by 36 inches (24 x 36). Where more than one sheet is required,
the sheets shall show the number of the sheet and the total number of sheets in
the plat, and match lines indicating where other sheets adjoin.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Copies of the preliminary plat must be presented to the Clerk at least
three weeks prior to the regular meeting of the Commission.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The City Clerk, upon receipt of 20 copies of the preliminary plat,
shall file one copy in the records of the City, shall retain one copy for
public inspection, and shall forward the remaining copies of the plat to the
Plats Officer.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The Plats Officer shall provide copies of the plat to the City
Engineer, and such other persons as necessary to review the plat; and shall
schedule the plat for consideration by the Commission.
170.13Â Â Â FEES ESTABLISHED.
Â Â Â At the time of submission of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall pay
a fee, as established by resolution of the Council, to the Clerk. In addition
to the plat filing fees, the subdivider shall be responsible for just and
reasonable costs incurred by the City during the course of construction of the
improvements for inspection, testing or other work deemed necessary by the City
to assure proper construction in accordance with the approved construction
drawings and applicable standards and ordinances.
170.14Â Â Â REVIEW OF PRELIMINARY PLAT.
Â Â Â The preliminary plat shall be reviewed by the Commission to determine its
conformity with these regulations and all other ordinances and regulations in
force affecting subdivisions. Copies of the preliminary plat may be transmitted
to other City or school officials, as the Commission deems necessary, for their
recommendations concerning matters within their jurisdiction. Their
recommendations, along with those of the City Engineer, shall be transmitted to
the Commission within three weeks from the date the plat is filed. The
Commission may confer with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the
kind and extent of such improvements to be made.
170.15Â Â Â ACTION BY THE COMMISSION.
Â Â Â The Commission shall, as soon as possible, but not more than 45Â days
thereafter pass upon the preliminary plat as originally submitted or modified.
If the Commission does not act within 45Â days, the preliminary plat shall be
deemed to be approved; provided, however, the subdivider may agree to an
extension of the time period not to exceed an additional 45Â days. It shall then
set forth its recommendations in writing whether of approval, modification or
disapproval.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In the event that substantial changes or modifications are made by the
Commission or the Commission recommends disapproval of the plat, it shall give
its reasons therefor and it may request and cause the revised preliminary plat
to be resubmitted in the same manner as the original plat.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the Commission recommends approval, it shall express its approval as
â€œTentative Approvalâ€ and state the conditions of such approval, if any.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The action of the Commission shall be documented on seven copies of the
preliminary plat, referenced and attached to any conditions determined. One
copy shall be returned to the subdivider, and one copy shall be retained by the
Commission, and five copies shall be referred to the Council.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The Council shall examine the plat, the report of the City Engineer,
the report of the Commission, and such other information as it deems necessary
or desirable. Upon such examination, the Council shall ascertain whether the
plat conforms to the ordinances and standards of the City, conforms to the
Comprehensive Plan and other duly adopted plans of the City, and will be
conducive to orderly growth and development of the City, in order to protect
the public health, safety, and welfare. Following such examination, the Council
may approve, approve subject to conditions, or disapprove the plat. If the
decision of the Council is to disapprove the plat, or to approve the plat
subject to conditions, the reasons therefor shall be set forth in writing in
the official records of the Council, and such decisions shall be provided to
the applicant. Action on the preliminary plat by the Council shall be taken
within 60 days of the filing of the plat with the Clerk.
170.16Â Â Â DURATION OF APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT.
Â Â Â The approval of a preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one
year, at the end of which time final approval must have been obtained. Any plat
not receiving final approval for some portion thereof within this period of
time shall be void, and the subdivider shall be required to resubmit a new plat
for approval subject to all new zoning restrictions and subdivision
regulations.
170.17Â Â Â CONTENTS OF PRELIMINARY PLAT.
Â Â Â Every proposed major subdivision shall be submitted for tentative approval
in the form of a preliminary plat prior to the submission of a final record
plat. The purpose of the preliminary plat and accompanying material is to
provide all facts needed for the Commission and Council to determine whether
the proposed subdivision is satisfactory from the standpoint of the public
interest. The following graphic and descriptive material is required to be
provided on the preliminary plat and in the accompanying material. The
preliminary plat shall be clearly marked â€œPreliminary Platâ€ and shall show, or
have attached thereto, the following:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Title, scale, north point and date.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The boundary of the area being platted, shown as a dark line with the
approximate length of boundary lines and the approximate location of the
property in reference to known section lines.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Present and proposed streets, alleys and sidewalks, with their rights-
of-way, in or adjoining the subdivision, including dedicated widths,
approximate gradients, types, and widths of surfaces, curbs, and planting
strips, and location of street lights, fire hydrants, and street signs.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The location, width, and dimensions of all streets and alleys, proposed
or existing, to be dedicated for public use.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The proposed names for all streets in the area being platted. Street
names shall be unlike any existing street names within the City.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The layout, number, and approximate dimensions of proposed lots,
showing dimensions, radii, chords, and the square foot areas of lots that are
not rectangular, and the lot and block number in numerical order.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Building setback or front yard lines.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Parcels of land proposed to be dedicated or reserved for schools,
parks, playgrounds, or other public, semi-public, or community purposes, or
shown for such purpose in the Comprehensive Plan or other adopted plans.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Present and proposed easements, showing locations, widths, purposes,
and limitations.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â The names and locations of adjacent subdivisions and the names of
record owners and location of adjoining parcels of unplatted land. A list of
all owners of record of property located within 200 feet of the subdivision
boundary shall be attached.
Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Boundaries of the highest known flood of record affecting the
subdivision and the source of information.
Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â Adjacent lakes or streams with a meander line established not less
than 20 feet back from the mean high water mark of the lake or stream.
Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â Existing blocks, lots and buildings.
Â Â Â 14.Â Â Â Present and proposed utility systems, including sanitary and storm
sewers, other drainage facilities, water lines, and other facilities with the
size, capacity, invert elevation, and location of each. If the subdivision is
within one mile of public sewer or water or both, notation shall be made of the
direction and distance to such facilities.
Â Â Â 15.Â Â Â Proposed name of the subdivision that shall not duplicate or resemble
existing subdivision names in the City.
Â Â Â 16.Â Â Â Names and addresses of the owner, subdivider, builder, and engineer or
surveyor who prepared the preliminary plat, and the surveyor who will prepare
the final plat.
Â Â Â 17.Â Â Â The legal description of the area being platted.
Â Â Â 18.Â Â Â Contours at vertical intervals of not less than five feet.
Â Â Â 19.Â Â Â Existing and proposed zoning of the proposed subdivision and adjoining
property.
Â Â Â 20.Â Â Â Location of all proposed monuments.
170.18Â Â Â INFORMATION IN ACCOMPANYING MATERIAL.
Â Â Â The following information shall accompany a preliminary plat when filing:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â General summary description of any protective covenants or private
restrictions to be incorporated in the final plat.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Table of the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Total acreage of subdivision.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Total number of lots.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Minimum, average, and maximum lot area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Acreage of public lands to be dedicated or reserved other than
streets.
170.19Â Â Â REQUIREMENTS OF THE FINAL PLAT.
Â Â Â The final plat shall conform to the preliminary plat as approved, and, if
desired by the subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the approved
preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record and develop at the
time; provided however, such portion shall conform to all requirements of this
chapter. The subdivider shall, within one year from the date of approval of the
preliminary plat, unless such time period has been extended, prepare and file
with the City Clerk 20 copies of the final plat and required attachments, as
set forth in this chapter. Except for a final plat for a minor subdivision as
set forth herein, no final plat shall be considered by the Council until and
unless a preliminary plat for the area included in the proposed final plat has
been approved and has not expired and become void as set forth above. The final
plat shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1 = 100 )
or larger. The scale used shall be clearly stated and graphically illustrated
by a bar scale drawn on every sheet showing any portion of the lands
subdivided. Sheet size shall be no greater than 24 inches by 36 inches or
smaller than 8Â½ inches by 11 inches and shall be of a size acceptable to the
County Auditor. If more than one sheet is used, each sheet shall clearly show
the number of the sheet, the total number of sheets included in the plat, and
match lines indicating where other sheets adjoin. An index sheet shall be
provided to show the relationship between the sheets. The final plat shall also
conform to all applicable statutes of the State of Iowa, agencies and
departments of the State of Iowa, standards and regulations as set forth by the
board of supervisors, commissions, boards, and agencies of Linn County, Iowa,
standards and regulations as set forth by the Council, boards, commissions, and
agencies of the City, including the Zoning Ordinance and construction and
design standards and the regulations as set forth herein.
170.20Â Â Â FEES ESTABLISHED.
Â Â Â At the time of submission of the final plat, the subdivider shall pay a fee,
as established by resolution of the Council, to the Clerk. In addition to the
plat filing fees, the subdivider shall be responsible for just and reasonable
costs incurred by the City during the course of construction of the
improvements for inspection, testing, or other work deemed necessary by the
City to assure proper construction in accordance with the approved construction
drawings and applicable standards and ordinances.
170.21Â Â Â SUBMISSION OF FINAL PLAT.
Â Â Â The subdivider shall prepare a final plat in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter and shall file with the Clerk an application in triplicate for
the final approval of the plat, and shall meet the following requirements:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Be accompanied by a minimum of 10 copies of the final plat.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Be accompanied by all formal irrevocable offers of dedication to the
public of all streets, City uses, utilities, and easements in a form approved
by the City Attorney.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Be presented to the Clerk at least four weeks prior to the regular
meeting of the Council.
170.22Â Â Â ACTION BY THE COUNCIL.
Â Â Â Upon receipt of the plat and written reports thereon, the Council shall
review the plat and attachments thereto. If the plat is found to conform to the
ordinances and standards of the City and the Comprehensive Plan and other duly
adopted plans, all as of the date of approval of the preliminary plat, and is
found to substantially conform to the preliminary plat, the Council shall
approve the plat, and shall cause its approval to be entered on the plat as
required by law. Action on the final plat by the Council shall be taken within
60 days of the date of filing the plat with the City Clerk. If the action is to
disapprove the plat, the reasons therefor shall be set forth in the official
records of the Council and such decision shall be provided to the subdivider.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In the event that said plat is disapproved by the Council, such
disapproval shall be expressed in writing and shall point out wherein said
proposed plat is objectionable.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â In the event that said plat is found to be acceptable and in accordance
with these regulations, the Council shall accept same.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The passage of a resolution by the Council accepting the plat shall
constitute final approval of the platting of the area shown on the final plat,
but the subdivider or owner shall cause such plat to be recorded within 180
days from the date of the passage of the resolution, in the office of the
County Recorder of the County where the land to be subdivided is located, and
shall file satisfactory evidence of such recording in the office of the Clerk
before the City shall recognize the plat as being in full force and effect.
170.23Â Â Â CONTENTS OF THE FINAL PLAT.
Â Â Â The plat shall be a permanent copy or a photographic print made on a stable
plastic film. Exact copies of the plat to be recorded shall be provided to and
filed by the County Recorder, Assessor and Auditor. The original plat drawing
shall remain the property of the registered surveyor. The final plat shall be
clearly marked â€œFinal Platâ€ and shall show the following:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The name of the subdivision.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Scale, and a graphic bar scale, north arrow, and date on each sheet.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All monuments of record, as required by Chapter 355, Code of Iowa.Â 
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Sufficient survey data to positively describe the bounds of every lot,
block, street, easement, or other area shown on the plat, as well as the outer
boundaries of the subdivided lands in accordance with Chapters 354 and 355 of
the Code of Iowa.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â All distance, bearing, curve, and other survey data, as required by
Chapter 355, Code of Iowa.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The course of every boundary line shown on the plat shall be indicated
by a direct bearing reference or by an angle between the boundary line and an
intersecting line having a shown bearing, except when the boundary line has an
irregular or constantly changing course, as along a body of water, or when a
description of the boundary line is better achieved by measurements shown at
points or intervals along a meander line having a shown course. All bearings
and angles shown shall be given to at least the nearest minute of arc.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Curve data shall be stated in terms of radius, central angle, tangent,
and length of curve. In all cases, the curve data must be shown for the line
affected.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The minimum unadjusted acceptable error of closure for all subdivision
boundaries shall be 1:10,000 and shall be 1:5,000 for any individual lot.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â When a lot or portion of the subdivision is bounded by an irregular
line, the major portion of that lot or subdivision shall be enclosed by a
meander line showing complete data with distances along all lines extending
beyond the enclosure to the irregular boundary shown with as much certainty as
can be determined or as â€œmore or less,â€ if variable. In all cases, the true
boundary shall be clearly indicated on the plat.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â All adjoining properties shall be identified, and where such adjoining
properties are a part of a recorded subdivision, the name of that subdivision
shall be shown. If the subdivision platted is a resubdivision of a part or the
whole of a previously recorded subdivision, sufficient ties shall be shown to
controlling lines appearing on the earlier plat to permit an overlay to be
made. Resubdivision shall be labeled as such in a subtitle following the name
of the subdivision wherever the name appears on the plat.
Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â The purpose of any easement shown on the plat shall be confined to
only those easements pertaining to public utilities including gas, power,
telephone, cable television, water, sewer; easements for trails, bike ways,
ingress and egress; and such drainage easements as are deemed necessary for the
orderly development of the land encompassed within the plat.
Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â A strip of land shall not be reserved by the subdivider unless the
land is of sufficient size and shape to be of some practical use or service as
determined by the Council.
Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â The purpose and accurate dimensions of all areas dedicated to the
public must be clearly indicated on the plat.
Â Â Â 14.Â Â Â Street names and clear designation of public alleys.
Â Â Â 15.Â Â Â Block and lot numbers.
Â Â Â 16.Â Â Â Name and address of the owner and subdivider.
Â Â Â 17.Â Â Â The plat shall be signed and acknowledged by the subdivision land
owner and spouse, if any.
Â Â Â 18.Â Â Â A statement by a registered land surveyor that the plat was prepared
by the surveyor or under the surveyorâ€™s direct personal supervision, signed and
dated by the surveyor and bearing the surveyorâ€™s Iowa registration number or
seal, and a sealed certification of the accuracy of the plat by the registered
land surveyor who drew the plat.
Â Â Â 19.Â Â Â If a portion of the subdivision is to have access on a State or County
jurisdiction road, a written and signed statement acknowledging and permitting
the access by the duly authorized officials of the appropriate jurisdiction is
required.
Â Â Â 20.Â Â Â Specification and engineering construction drawings shall be provided
that include cross-sections and details of all public improvements. Elevations
shall refer to mean sea level as exhibited in standard U.S. Geological Survey
maps. Specifications and references shall meet those required by the Cityâ€™s
construction and specification standards, including a site grading plan for the
entire subdivision.
170.24Â Â Â ATTACHMENTS TO THE FINAL PLAT.
Â Â Â The following shall be attached to accompany any final plat:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A surveyorâ€™s certificate with a complete and correct legal description
of the subdivision land.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A statement by the proprietors and their spouses, if any, that the plat
is prepared with their free consent and in accordance with their desire, signed

deeds. The statement by the proprietors may also include a dedication to the

parks, open areas, school property, or other public use, if the dedication is
approved by the Council.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A statement from the mortgage holders or lienholders, if any, that the
plat is prepared with their free consent and in accordance with their desire,
signed and acknowledged before an officer authorized to take the acknowledgment
of deeds. An affidavit and bond as provided for in Section 354.12 of the Code
of Iowa may be recorded in lieu of the consent of the mortgage or lienholder.
When a mortgage or lienholder consents to the subdivision, a release of
mortgage or lien shall be recorded for any areas conveyed to the City or
dedicated to the public.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â An opinion by an attorney-at-law who has examined the abstract of title
of the land being platted. The opinion shall state the names of the proprietors
and holders of mortgages, liens or other encumbrances on the land being platted
and shall note the encumbrances, along with any bonds securing the
encumbrances. Utility easements shall not be construed to be encumbrances for

Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A certificate of the County Treasurer that the land is free from
certified taxes and certified special assessments or that the land is free from
certified taxes and that the certified special assessments are secured by bond
in compliance with Section 354.12 of the Code of Iowa.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A statement of restrictions of all types that run with the land and
become covenants in the deeds of lots.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â A resolution and certificate for approval by the Council and for
signatures of the Mayor and Clerk.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A certificate by the City Engineer that all required improvements have
been satisfactorily completed in accordance with the construction plans as
approved and in substantial compliance with the approved preliminary plat.
Prior to such certification, â€œas-builtâ€ plans for all improvements shall have
been provided to the City Engineer. In lieu thereof, the City Clerk may certify
that a performance bond guaranteeing completion has been approved by the City
Attorney and filed with the Clerk, or that the Council has agreed that the City
will provide the necessary improvements and installations and assess the costs
against the subdivider of future property owners in the subdivision.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â If private streets or other private improvements have been approved, an
agreement in the form of a covenant running with the land, in a form approved
by the City Attorney, providing for the construction or reconstruction of any
improvements to meet City Standards, and the assessment of all costs to the
property owners in the event of annexation and dedication and acceptance shall
be required.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â The encumbrance bond, if any.
170.25Â Â Â RESUBDIVISION OF LAND.
Â Â Â The following requirements shall govern the resubdividing of land.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â For any change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat, if
such change affects any street layout shown on such map, or area reserved for
public use indicated on the map, or any lot line, or if it affects any map or
plan legally established prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling
subdivisions, such parcel shall be approved by the same procedure, rules, and
regulations for a subdivision.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whenever a parcel of land is subdivided and the subdivision plat shows
one or more lots containing more than one acre of land and there are
indications that such lots will eventually be resubdivided into smaller
building sites, the Commission and Council may require that such parcel of land
allow for future opening of streets and the ultimate extension of adjacent
streets. Easements providing for the future opening and extension of such
streets may be made a requirement of the plat.
170.26Â Â Â AUTHORIZATION TO INSTALL IMPROVEMENTS.
Â Â Â The approval of the preliminary plat shall constitute authorization by the
Council for the installation of improvements as required by this ordinance, and
as shown on the preliminary plat; provided, no such improvement shall be
constructed or installed until and unless the plans, profiles, cross sections,
and specifications for the construction of such improvement have been submitted
to, and approved in writing by the City Engineer.
170.27Â Â Â COMPLETION AND ACCEPTANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS.
Â Â Â Before the Council will approve the final plat, all of the foregoing
improvements shall be constructed and accepted by formal resolution of
acceptance, the City Engineer shall report that said improvements meet all City
specifications and ordinances or other City requirements, and the agreements
between the subdivider and the City, and are free and clear of all liens and
encumbrances on the property and public improvements thus dedicated.
170.28Â Â Â PERFORMANCE BOND.
Â Â Â The Council in its discretion may waive the requirement that the applicant
complete and dedicate all public improvements prior to approving the final
plat, and that, as an alternative, the applicant post a bond at the time of
application for final plat approval in the amount estimated by the Council as
sufficient to secure to the City the satisfactory construction, installation,
and dedication of the uncompleted portion of required improvements. In
addition:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Such performance bond shall comply with all statutory requirements and
shall be satisfactory to the City Attorney as to form, sufficiency, and manner
of execution as set forth in these regulations.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The period within which required improvements must be completed shall
be specified by the Council in the resolution approving the final plat, shall
be incorporated in the bond, and shall not exceed one year from date of final
approval.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The performance bond shall be approved by the Council as to the amount
and surety and conditions satisfactory to the Council. The Commission may, upon
proof of difficulty, recommend to the Council extension of the completion date
set forth in such bond for a maximum period of one additional year. The Council
may at any time during the period of such bond accept a substitution of
principal or sureties on the bond.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The applicant shall build and pay for all costs of temporary
improvements required by the Council and shall maintain same for the period
specified by the Council. Prior to construction of any temporary facility or
improvement, the developer shall file with the City a separate suitable bond
for temporary facilities, which bond shall insure that the temporary facilities
will be properly constructed, maintained and removed.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â For subdivisions for which no performance bond has been posted, if the
improvements are not completed within the period specified by the Council in
the resolution approving the plat, the approval shall be deemed to have
expired. In those cases where a performance bond has been posted and required
improvements have not been installed within the terms of such performance bond,
the City may declare the bond to be in default and require that all the
improvements be installed regardless of the extent of the building development
at the time the bond is declared to be in default.
170.29Â Â Â RELEASE OR REDUCTION OF PERFORMANCE BOND.
Â Â Â The performance bond may not be released or reduced except as follows:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The Council will not accept dedication of required improvements, or
release or reduce a performance bond, until the City Engineer has submitted a
certificate stating that all required improvements have been satisfactorily
completed and until the applicantâ€™s engineer has certified to the City through
submission of detailed â€œas-builtâ€ plans of the subdivision indicating location,
dimensions, materials, and other information required by the city, that all
public improvements are in accordance with construction plans for the
subdivision.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A performance bond may be reduced upon actual dedication of public
improvements and then only to the ratio that the public improvement dedicated
bears to the total public improvements for the plat.
170.30Â Â Â INSPECTION.
Â Â Â All improvements shall be inspected to ensure compliance with the
requirements of this chapter. The cost of such inspection shall be borne by the
developer and shall be the actual cost of the inspection to the City. The
subdivider shall notify the City not less than 24 hours in advance of readiness
for required inspections. To ensure that costs are economical for developers
and that construction is being done to Code requirements and standards, the
following testing procedures will be required on the installation of all
improvements in new subdivisions:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Compaction tests are required on sanitary sewer main trench backfill:
ASTM D1557; three tests per 200 LF of trench where compacted or ordinary
backfill is specified; at each 200 LF, two of the tests shall be at
intermediate depths as directed by the City Engineer and the other test at the
surface.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Compaction tests are required on water main and storm sewer trench
backfill: ASTM D1557; two tests per 200 LF of trench where compacted or
ordinary backfill is specified; at each 200 LF, one of the tests shall be at an
intermediate depth as directed by the City Engineer and the other test at the
surface.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Backfill material shall be tested for each water and sanitary sewer
service line that crosses the proposed roadway at an intermediate depth and at
the surface. Pavement subgrade shall also be tested approximately every 400 LF
of road length with one test on each side. The following is a tabulation of the
required number of tests for each type of utility line:
Â 
ITEM                             TEST PER ITEM
Sanitary Sewer Main              3 tests per 200 LF
Water Main and Storm Sewer       2 tests per 200 LF
Sanitary Sewer Service Crossings 2 tests per crossing
Water Service Crossings          2 tests per crossing
Pavement Subgrade                2 tests per 400 LF
Â 
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A tandem axle unit will perform a wheel load test. The vehicle will
apply 12,000 to 16,000 pounds of weight for each rear axle. This load test
shall be required immediately preceding the performance of paving work or the
construction of base and is to determine uniformity of subgrade resistance.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â If the compaction on pavement subgrade does not meet requirements, the
developer may propose corrective treatments, including granular subsurfacing,
lime or fly ash treatment, or geogrid. This is to be approved and inspected by
the City Engineer. Costs incurred for the alternate method are at the
developerâ€™s expense.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The developer shall select a qualified independent testing laboratory
to perform the compaction tests, as approved by the City Engineer. If the
developer does not select the independent testing laboratory, the City shall
choose for them. In either case, the compaction test laboratory is to invoice
the developer directly for this service. It is the developerâ€™s responsibility
to pay for all inspections.
170.31Â Â Â RECORDING OF PLAT.
Â Â Â No subdivision plat, resubdivision plat or street dedication within the City
or within two miles of the corporate limits of the City, as provided in Section
354.9, Code of Iowa, shall be filed for record with the County Recorder, or
recorded by the County Recorder, until a final plat of such subdivision,
resubdivision, or street dedication has been reviewed and approved in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Upon the approval of the final
plat by the Council, it shall be the duty of the subdivider to immediately file
such plat with the County Auditor and County Recorder, as required by law. Such
approval shall be revocable after 90 days, unless such plat has been duly
recorded and evidence thereof filed with the City Clerk within such 90 days.
170.32Â Â Â MAINTENANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS.
Â Â Â Improvements shall be maintained and a maintenance bond provided as follows:
The owner and subdivider shall be required to maintain all improvements on the
individual subdivided lots and provide for snow removal on streets and
sidewalks, if required, until acceptance of said improvements by the Council.
If there are any occupied residences on a street not dedicated to the City, the
City may, on 12 hoursâ€™ notice, plow the street or effect emergency repairs and
charge same to the owner and subdivider.
170.33Â Â Â MAINTENANCE BOND REQUIRED.
Â Â Â The owner and subdivider of the land being platted shall be required to
provide to the City proper maintenance bonds satisfactory to the City so as to
insure that for a period of two years from the date of acceptance of any
improvement the owner and subdivider shall be responsible to maintain such
improvement in good repair.
170.34Â Â Â DEFERRAL OR WAIVER OF REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
Â Â Â Required improvements may be deferred or waived as follows:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The Council may defer or waive at the time of final approval, subject
to appropriate conditions, the provision of any or all such improvements as in
its judgment are not requisite in the interests of the public health, safety,
and general welfare, or which are inappropriate because of inadequacy or lack
of connecting facilities.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whenever it is deemed necessary by the Council to defer the
construction of any improvement required herein because of incompatible grades,
future planning, inadequacy or lack of connecting facilities, or for other
reasons, the applicant shall pay the applicantâ€™s share of the costs of the
future improvements to the City prior to the approval of the final plat, or the
applicant may post a bond insuring completion of said improvements upon demand
of the City.
170.35Â Â Â IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED.
Â Â Â The subdivider shall, at his or her expense, install and construct all
improvements required by this chapter. All required improvements shall be
designed, installed, and constructed in accordance with the design and
construction standards established for such improvements by the City, and as
shown on the approved preliminary plat.
170.36Â Â Â STANDARDS PRESCRIBED.
Â Â Â The standards set forth in this chapter shall be considered the minimum
standards necessary to protect the public health, safety, and general welfare.
170.37Â Â Â CONFORMANCE TO APPLICABLE RULES AND REGULATIONS.
Â Â Â In addition to the requirements established herein, all subdividers shall
comply with the following laws, rules and regulations:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All applicable statutes of the State of Iowa.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any comprehensive plan, public utilities plan, and capital improvements
program of the City.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The requirements and rules of State agencies such as the State
Departments of Health, Transportation, and Natural Resources where applicable.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The standards and regulations of the County Board of Supervisors and
County Commissions, Boards, and agencies where applicable.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The standards and regulations adopted by the Council, Boards,
Commissions and agencies of the City.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Plat approval may be withheld if a subdivision is not in conformance
with the above guides, or policy and purposes of these regulations.
170.38Â Â Â MONUMENTATION.
Â Â Â Monuments shall be in conformance with the following requirements:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Prior to the offering of the plat or any subdivision for record, the
surveyor shall confirm the prior establishment of permanent control monuments
at each controlling corner on the boundaries of the parcel or tract of land
being subdivided. If no permanent control monuments exist, the surveyor shall
place the monuments. Control monuments shall be constructed of reasonably
permanent material solidly embedded in the ground and capable of being detected
by commonly used magnetic or electronic equipment. The surveyor shall affix a
cap of reasonably inert material bearing an embossed or stencil cut marking of
the Iowa registration number of the surveyor to the top of each monument which
the surveyor places.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â At least a minimum number of two (2) survey control monuments are
required to be placed before the recording of a subdivision provided the
surveyor or engineer includes in his or her statement a declaration that
additional monuments shall be placed before a date specified in the statement
or within one year from the date the subdivision is recorded, whichever is
earlier.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Control monuments shall be placed at the following locations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â At every corner and angle point of every lot, block, or parcel of
land created.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â At every point of intersection of the outer boundary of the
subdivision with an existing or created right-of-way line of any street,
railroad, or other way.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â At every point of curve, tangency, reversed curve, or compounded
curve on every right-of-way line established.
When the placement of a monument required by this chapter at the prescribed
location is impractical, a reference monument shall be established near the
prescribed location. If a point requiring monumentation has been previously
monumented, the existence of the monument shall be confirmed by the surveyor.
170.39Â Â Â LAND SUITABILITY.
Â Â Â No land shall be subdivided which is found to be unsuitable for subdividing
by reason of flooding, ponding, poor drainage, adverse soil conditions, adverse
geological formations, unsatisfactory topography, or other conditions likely to
be harmful to the public health, safety, or general welfare, unless such
unsuitable conditions are corrected to the satisfaction of the City. If land is
found to be unsuitable for subdivision for any of the reasons cited in this
section, the Council shall state its reasons in writing and afford the
subdivider an opportunity to present data regarding such unsuitability.
Thereafter, the Council may reaffirm, modify, or withdraw its determination
regarding such unsuitability.
170.40Â Â Â BLOCK AND LOT STANDARDS.
Â Â Â The following standards shall apply to the layout of blocks and lots in all
subdivisions, and to the extent possible, in all resubdivisions:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The size and shape of all lots shall comply with all requirements of
the Zoning Ordinance for the zone in which the lot is located.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All lots shall abut a public street, or upon an approved private
street, with a minimum frontage of at least 35 feet measured as a straight line
between the two front lot corners.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Reversed frontage lots are prohibited. Double frontage lots shall only
be permitted where abutting a major street and a minor street, and such lots
shall front only on the minor street.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â All lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or
radial to curved street lines, except where, in the judgment of the Council, a
variation to this provision will provide a better street and lot layout.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Lots shall be laid out so as to provide positive drainage away from all
buildings, and individual lot drainage shall be coordinated with the general
storm drainage pattern for the area. Drainage shall be designed so as to avoid
concentration of storm drainage water from each lot to adjacent lots.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Building lines conforming with zoning standards shall be known on all
lots within the platted area. Where the subdivided area is not under zoning
control, the Council may require building lines in accordance with the needs of
each subdivision.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots of
appropriate depths. Exceptions shall be permitted in blocks adjacent to
arterial streets, railroads, or waterways.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â No residential block shall be longer than 1,300 feet or shorter than
300 feet measured from street line to street line. The width of blocks should
be arranged so as to allow two tiers of lots, with utility easement. Exceptions
shall be permitted in blocks adjacent to arterial streets, railroads, or
waterways.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Pedestrian crosswalks, not less than 10 feet wide, may be required by
the Council through the center of blocks more than 700 feet in length.
Pedestrian crosswalks shall not exceed 12 percent in grade unless steps of an
approved design are to be constructed.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â In blocks over 700 feet in length, the Council may require a public
way or an easement at least 10 feet in width, at or near the center of the
block, for use by pedestrians.
170.41Â Â Â STREETS, GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
Â Â Â The improvements set forth below shall be considered the minimum
improvements necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare. Under
some circumstances the City may require, as a condition for approval of the
plat, dedication and improvement of a street having width greater than
necessary to meet the needs of the platted area, but necessary to complete the
City street system as it relates to both the area being platted and other
areas. In such event, the City will pay the subdivider the difference in cost
of improving the wider street and the street width reasonable to meet the
foreseeable needs of the subdivision taken alone. The streets shall, upon final
approval and acceptance by the City, become the property of the City. The
following standards shall apply to all streets to be located within the
subdivision:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The subdivider of land being subdivided shall provide the grading of
the entire street right-of-way, alley, or public place and provide appropriate
paving, including curb and gutter on all streets. All streets or alleys shall
be of such width and shall be so constructed as to meet the standards of the
City.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No subdivision shall be approved unless the area to be subdivided has
frontage on and access from an existing street.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Street grade shall align to existing streets, and all grades for
streets shall be as approved by the City or as provided for herein.
170.42Â Â Â TOPOGRAPHY AND ARRANGEMENT.
Â Â Â Streets shall be in conformance with the following requirements related to
topography and arrangement:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Streets shall be related appropriately to the topography. All streets
shall be arranged so as to obtain as many as possible of the building sites at,
or above, the grades of the streets. Grades of streets shall conform as closely
as possible to the original topography. A combination of steep grades and
curves shall be avoided.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Streets shall provide for the continuation of arterial and collector
streets from adjoining platted areas, and the extension of such streets into
adjoining unplatted areas. Where a plat encompasses the location for an
arterial or collector street proposed in the Comprehensive Plan, the plat shall
provide for such street.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All arterials shall be properly related to special traffic generators
such as industries, business districts, schools, churches, and shopping
centers; to population densities; and to the pattern of existing and proposed
land uses.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Local streets should be designed to discourage through traffic while
safely connecting to collector or arterial streets.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract
to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions,
or unless in the opinion of the Council such extension isÂ not necessary or
desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with
theÂ existing layout or advantageous future development of adjacent tracts.
170.43Â Â Â ACCESS TO STATE OR COUNTY JURISDICTIONAL ROADS.
Â Â Â Whenever any part of a subdivision is designed with access to a road under
State or County jurisdiction, permission for access to such roads shall be
obtained from the appropriate jurisdiction and such access shall be designed
according to the standards of the appropriate jurisdiction.
170.44Â Â Â ACCESS TO ARTERIAL STREETS.
Â Â Â Where a subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed arterial
street, the Council may require that lot access to such streets be limited by
one of the following means:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Lots shall be designed so as to back onto the primary arterial and
front onto a parallel municipal service street; no access shall be provided
from the arterial street, and screening shall be provided in a strip of land
along the rear property line of such lots.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A series of cul-de-sacs entered from and designed generally at right
angles to such a parallel street, with the read lines of their terminal lots
backing onto the arterial street.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A frontage or service road, separated from the primary arterial by a
planting or grass strip and having access thereto at suitable points.
170.45Â Â Â STREET NAMES.
Â Â Â Streets that are or will become extensions of existing streets shall be
given the same name as existing streets. New street names shall not be the same
or sound similar to existing street names. All street names shall be at the
approval of the Council. Street name signs are to be placed at all
intersections within or abutting the subdivision, the type and location of
which are to be approved by the Council. The City shall install all street name
signs. The owner and subdivider shall deposit with the City at the time of
final subdivision approval, the estimated cost of installation of each street
sign required by the Council.
170.46Â Â Â STREET LIGHTS.
Â Â Â Installations of street lights shall be required in accordance with design,
construction, and specification standards approved by the Council.
170.47Â Â Â DEAD-END AND PRIVATE STREETS.
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Dead-end streets are prohibited, except where a street is planned to
continue past the subdividerâ€™s property, a temporary dead end may be allowed. A
T- or L-shaped turnaround shall be provided on all temporary dead-end streets,
with the notation on the subdivision plat that land outside normal street
right- of-way shall revert to abutters when the street is continued. The length
of dead-end streets may be limited by the Council.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Private streets, not dedicated to the City, shall be avoided. The
Council may approve a private street where unusual conditions make a private
street desirable, provided adequate covenants or other legal documents ensure
that the City will not have or need to assume any maintenance or other
responsibility for such street.
170.48Â Â Â STREET DESIGN STANDARDS.
Â Â Â In order to provide for streets of suitable location, width, and improvement
to accommodate prospective traffic and afford satisfactory access to police,
firefighting, snow removal, sanitation, and street maintenance equipment, and
to coordinate streets so as to compose a convenient system and avoid undue
hardships to adjoining properties, the following design standards for streets
are required:
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A tangent at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse
curves on municipal arterial and collector streets, and 25 feet on municipal
local streets.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point
by more than 10 degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius
adequate to insure a sight distance of not less than 100 feet for municipal
service and collector streets, and of such greater radii as the council shall
determine for special cases.
170.49Â Â Â MINIMUM ROADWAY AND RIGHT-OF-WAY STANDARDS.
Â Â Â Minimum roadway and right-of-way standards shall be as follows (wider
rights-of-way and roadways may be required where deemed appropriate by the City
Engineer and the Council):
Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Municipal arterial streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less
than 80 feet and a roadway width of not less than 49Â feet.
Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Municipal collector streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less
than 66 feet and a roadway width of not less than 31 feet.
Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Municipal local streets shall have a right-of-way of not less than 60
feet and a roadway width of not less than 28 feet.
Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Cul-de-sacs shall meet all the requirements for local streets and, in
addition, shall provide a turnaround with the outer edge of paving at a 40-
foot radius and the right-of-way at a 60-foot radius.
Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Streets that connect with other streets, or loop streets, are
preferable for maintenance, fire protection, and circulation. Every effort
shall be made to minimize the use of cul-de-sacs. Cul-de-sacs shall not exceed
500 feet in length. The provisions set forth herein shall be adhered to.
Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Street grades, wherever feasible, shall not exceed the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Municipal arterial streets â€“ 8 percent.
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Municipal collector streets â€“ 10 percent.
Â Â Â Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Municipal local streets â€“ 12 percent.
Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â All changes in street alignment shall be connected with horizontal
curves, and all changes in street grade shall be connected by vertical curves
of minimum length in feet designed in accordance with AASHTO â€œGreen Bookâ€
provisions. Any changes in street grade shall conform to design and
construction standards as adopted by the Council.
Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â No street grade shall be less than one-half (1/2) of one percent,
unless extreme conditions warrant.
Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â After sewer, water, and other utilities to be located underground
within the right-of-way have been installed by the owner and subdivider, the
owner and subdivider shall construct curbs and gutters and shall surface or
cause to be surfaced, roadways according to design and construction standards
as adopted by the Council.
Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â The pavement slab shall be constructed of the following materials:
Â Â Â Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Nonreinforced Portland cement concrete conforming to the Iowa
Department of Transportation C-4 mix or M-4,Â as applicable; orÂ 
Â Â Â Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Full depth asphaltic concrete hot mix conforming to theÂ Iowa
Department of Transportation standards for Type A surface course. Four inches
of granular base material may be substituted for one inch of asphaltic concrete
hot mix. The granular base material shall be a minimum of four inches thick and
a maximum of 12 inches thick. The granular base material must conform to the
Iowa Department of Transportation standards for crushed stone special backfill.
Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â The recommended pavement thickness in inches is as outlined in the
following table:
Â

Arterial              9 *                      11 *

*Â Â Â Thickness requirements for arterials are intended as a guide only.
Specific projects will be designed on the basis of soil conditions and
